message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A CD4 count of 98 suggests severe immunodeficiency, increasing the likelihood of opportunistic fungal infections. Among the options, esophagitis caused by Candida is common in HIV-positive patients and very rare in immunocompetent hosts. Oral thrush and vaginitis can occur in both immunocompetent and immunocompromised individuals, while endocarditis caused by Candida is more common in immunocompromised individuals but can occur in both.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Candida esophagitis is more commonly seen in those with weakened immune systems, such as AIDS patients with low CD4 counts. While oral thrush and vaginitis can occur in both immunocompromised and immunocompetent hosts, endocarditis is typically associated with prolonged IV use and is not specific to immunocompromised patients.

We refer to UpToDate for help. One of the most common candidal infections seen in HIV-positive patients with low CD4 counts is esophagitis. While oral thrush and vaginitis can also be seen in immunocompromised patients, they are not considered rare in this population. However, endocarditis is rare in both immunocompetent and immunocompromised patients.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only candidal esophagitis is a common opportunistic infection in patients with HIV/AIDS. Oral thrush and vaginitis can also occur, but they are not uncommon in immunocompetent patients, and endocarditis is rare in both immunocompromised and immunocompetent patients.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is immunocompromised due to HIV infection and a low CD4 count, putting him at risk for various fungal infections. While candidal infections such as oral thrush and vaginitis can be seen in both immunocompromised and immunocompetent hosts, esophagitis is rare in immunocompetent hosts and more commonly seen in those with HIV/AIDS. Endocarditis is also a possible complication of candidal infections, but it is not specific to immunocompromised patients.
We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, all can be seen in an HIV positive patient, but esophagitis caused by candida is rare in immunocompetent hosts.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A CD4 count of less than 200 puts the patient at risk for candidiasis. While oral thrush and vaginitis can occur in both immunocompromised and immunocompetent hosts, esophagitis (inflammation of the esophagus) is rare in an immunocompetent host and is usually seen in HIV-positive patients with a CD4 count below 100. Endocarditis (infection of the heart lining) is also possible in immunocompromised patients but is not a common manifestation of candidal infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A patient with HIV and low CD4 count is more susceptible to fungal infections, including Candida. While oral thrush and vaginitis are common candidal infections in immunocompromised individuals, esophagitis is specifically rare in immunocompetent hosts. Endocarditis may not be directly related to a Candida infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Candida infections are more common in immunocompromised patients, and esophagitis is a common manifestation in HIV-positive patients with a low CD4 count. Oral thrush can occur in both immunocompromised and immunocompetent hosts, while vaginitis and endocarditis are less likely to occur in this patient population.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Candidal esophagitis is rare in immunocompetent patients but can be seen in immunocompromised patients, especially those with HIV/AIDS and low CD4 counts. Oral thrush and vaginitis are more common in both immunocompromised and immunocompetent patients. Endocarditis is a rare and serious complication of candidal infections, but it can occur in both immunocompromised and immunocompetent patients.
